intro: Poecilocnemis cincinnata, commonly known as the cinnabar beetle, is a species of leafhopper native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its distinctive red and black coloration, which serves as a warning signal to potential predators. The plant it inhabits, typically various species of oak, provides both shelter and a source of nutrients. Its life cycle involves laying eggs on the undersides of leaves, where the nymphs develop through several instars before reaching adulthood. This species plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat through its feeding habits and interactions with other organisms.
